summary: This is an email forwarding a New York Times opinion column by Gail Collins from July 10, 2019, criticizing Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta for his role in the lenient 2008 plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein and discussing Donald Trump's past association with Epstein. The column also critiques Acosta's performance as Labor Secretary and the Trump administration's broader ethical failings.

persons.name: Gail Collins
persons.context: Author of the New York Times opinion column criticizing Alexander Acosta's handling of the Epstein case and discussing Trump's past association with Epstein.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Publicly defended his role in overseeing the prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, brokering a lenient plea deal in 2008. The column criticizes his performance as Labor Secretary and his failure to adequately prosecute Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Rich individual who liked to have sex with underage girls, received a lenient plea deal in 2008 brokered by Acosta. Now facing new sex-trafficking charges in New York.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Defended Acosta, had a past friendship with Epstein in the early 2000s which he later disavowed. The column criticizes his administration's ethical standards.

persons.name: Mick Mulvaney
persons.context: Trump's Acting Chief of Staff who has been trying to take control and reportedly pushed out Acosta's chief of staff.

connections.description: Acosta, as a federal prosecutor, brokered a lenient plea deal for Epstein in 2008.
Trump described Epstein as a 'terrific guy' and 'lot of fun to be with' in 2002, but claims they had a falling out and haven't spoken in 15 years.
Trump has been defending Acosta's job performance as Labor Secretary despite the Epstein scandal.
Mulvaney has been trying to take control and reportedly pushed out Acosta's chief of staff.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal
events.description: Alexander Acosta, as a federal prosecutor, brokered a lenient plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein involving 13 months in prison with work release.

events.title: Acosta's Public Defense
events.description: Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta publicly defended his role in the Epstein prosecution, claiming it was the best deal possible.

events.title: Trump's Comments on Epstein
events.description: Donald Trump praised Jeffrey Epstein in a New York magazine interview, calling him a 'terrific guy' and 'lot of fun'.

events.title: New York Federal Prosecution
events.description: Federal prosecutors in New York bring new sex-trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: Alexander Acosta publicly defended his role in brokering a lenient 2008 plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein that involved only 13 months in prison with work release.
Donald Trump had a past social relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, praising him in a 2002 interview but later claiming a falling out.
The victims of Epstein's abuse were not informed about the plea deal negotiations and were described as too 'scared and traumatized' to be good witnesses.
New York federal prosecutors have brought new sex-trafficking charges against Epstein, separate from the 2008 Florida case.
Trump administration insiders, including Mick Mulvaney, have been critical of Acosta's performance as Labor Secretary and pushed out his chief of staff.
